6.09.text: When someone dies at home or in a nursing home the first contact should be with the deceased's doctor.

11.79.text:
If satisfied with the cause of death, the
doctor will issue the Medical Certificate

15.41.text:
of Cause of Death. You will need this when
you come to registering the death.

19.80.text: If someone dies in a nursing home, their staff should make contact with the doctor on your behalf.

26.82.text:
In either case, after the doctor has been
informed, you should contact your local funeral home.

32.21.text:
Your local Funeral Director will arrange a
suitable time, day or night, to visit you

36.23.text:
to discuss your requirements and bringing
the deceased into their care.

41.54.text: When someone dies in hospital the hospital staff will contact you and arrange for a doctor

45.46.text:
to issue the Medical Certificate of Cause
of Death.

49.16.text: If you have already decided whether the funeral will be a burial or cremation then the doctor

53.33.text: should be informed to ensure they can make arrangements for any additional documentation to be completed.

59.61.text: When someone dies unexpectedly or where the doctor is unable to issue the Medical Certificate of Cause of Death

63.76.text: it is normal for the Coroner or Procurator Fiscal in Scotland to be involved.

70.31.text: Whatever the circumstances, contact your local funeral home as soon as possible.

75.09.text: Your Funeral Director will be able to explain the Coroner's procedures to you.

77.81.text:
They will also be able to arrange a suitable
time, day or night, to visit you to discuss

79.01.text:
the funeral arrangements and bringing the
deceased into our care.

79.68.text: When someone dies away from home or abroad your Funeral Director can offer advice on

83.47.text: arranging to bring the deceased home.

86.67.text:
You can find more information by visiting
www.co-operativefuneralcare.co.uk
